"But still, I agree with the concept that buying hardware should at least be
*considered* an option ..."

That was the point. Look at ALL the technical optinons and then judge them
against risk/cost/ and so on. I just have seen too many times people propose
the "technical elegant solution" which was not "optimal from a business
perspective".

>It seems your experience is somewhat limited ...

Well. My knee jirk response is to take exception to that. :-)

I am definitely new to the Java world and my experience is definitely
limited in this area. I come from the database world where I use to
run/administer/code the databases that processed online credit card
applications and on which people could look at their credit card statements
online for Fleet. So, I am very familiar w/ big roll outs.

Thanks guys for taking the time to engage a newbie.

> Elliotte Harold wrote:
>
> > Speaking as one of those professionals, in a desktop or server
> > environment buying RAM is cheaper than almost any other alternative.
> > Most especially it's cheaper than rewriting the code to use less memory.
> >
> > Frankly, I'd fire a consultant who recommended continued hacking at $80
> > an hour to save a byte here or a byte there instead of spending a few
> > bucks to upgrade the RAM. In 2006 anyone who's running a desktop or a
> > server with less than a gigabyte of RAM is being penny wise and very
> > pound foolish.

It seems your experience is somewhat limited ...

2 real scenarios:

1000 servers in outlets of a Europe-wide retailer, having been installed
over the last 5 years (sometimes, for tax reasons, with considerable
quarrels with "deciders" in different countries = there are even older
machines around, because they are now completely written off [fiscally] and
hence "are most valuable" [in the eyes of accounting]).
In 2001, physical mem size was not 1GB or 2GB, but 256MB or (at most) 512MB.
Ok - let's upgrade to 1 gig:
* Travel expense for technicians to all those locations ... large enough.
* Outsourcing the memory upgrading?: With the required quality (hardware
change must happen overnight, 100% guaranteed to run next day in the morning
when shop opens), outsourcing cannot be bought consistently throughout all
countries. (Why aren't there two servers so that memory change needn't be
100% perfect? ... is was simply never necessary).

Net effect: It is (much!) cheaper to optimize some(! - critical, usually
newer) programs to run in 256MB even today, with 80 EUR/hour for a few weeks
of work.

---

Similarly for a company that leases out HW+SW for a special sort of
retailers: 5 year contracts, around 10000 widely dispersed customers =
replacement rate of 2000/year = around 10/day. Highest cost of operations
are technicians' travel expenses; therefore the pressure to keep HW exactly
the same for 5 years (until end of lease - then, all HW is routinely
changed) is very high.

---

If you have a better idea how to deal with these situations in the
short...medium run, please tell us!

* send memory over the network? ;-) (maybe there's *something* to this -
honestly! sometimes weird ideas are worth to look at -, but we currently
fail to see the realistic solution following from this ...)

* re-architecture everything to run centrally/on some server farms!!! ... ?
:-( not always possible because of
** fiscal laws that require data to be accessible in the country of the
business [yes, there are laws like this; e.g. in France]
** up-times, bandwidths and other qualities of networks (many customers are
on ISDN lines; throughout Europe, network QoS varies considerably)
** in 2nd scenario, one USP is actually that data are on-site.
** and more ...

But still, I agree with the concept that buying hardware should at least be
*considered* an option when dealing with memory problems - so that there is
a comparison of price tags of SW optimzation vs. HW replacement/upgrading
for a qualified management decision which way to go.

Regards
Harald M.
